question.name: 19.2.4.1 Solving exact equations
question.questiontext:
Solving exact equations

As we have seen, the differential equation \( \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(yx)=3x^2\) has solution \(y=x^2+C/x \). In the solution, \(x^2\) is called the definite part and \(C/x\) is called the indefinite part (containing the arbitrary constant of integration). If we take the definite part of this solution, i.e. \(y_\text{d}=x^2\), then \[ \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(y_\text{d}\cdot x)=\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(x^2\cdot x)=\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(x^3)=3x^2.\] Hence \(y_\text{d}=x^2\) is a solution of the differential equation.

Now if we take the indefinite part of the solution i.e. \(y_\text{i}=C/x\) then \[ \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(y_\text{i}\cdot x)=\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left({C\over x}\cdot x\right)=\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{ \mathrm{d}x}(C)=0.\] It is always the case that the general solution of an exact equation is in two parts: a definite part \(y_\text{d}(x)\)which is a solution of the differential equation and an indefinite part \(y_\text{i}(x)\) which satisfies a simpler version of the differential equation in which the right-hand side is zero.
